title: Ellora Caves
summary: The Ellora Caves, a UNESCO World Heritage Site in Aurangabad, India, constitute one of the world's largest rock-cut cave complexes. Featuring Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain artwork dating from 600–1000 AD, they exemplify ancient Indian rock-cut architecture and religious harmony. Among its 100+ caves, 34 are open to the public, including the monumental Kailash temple (Cave 16), the largest monolithic rock excavation dedicated to Shiva. Constructed primarily by the Rashtrakuta and Yadava dynasties with funding from royals and traders, the site served as temples, pilgrim rests, and a commercial hub. Today, it remains a major tourist attraction and a protected monument.
key_points: A UNESCO World Heritage Site located in Aurangabad, India.
One of the world's largest rock-cut cave complexes, featuring artwork from 600–1000 AD.
Includes Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain caves, showcasing religious harmony in ancient India.
Cave 16, the Kailash temple, is the largest single monolithic rock excavation globally, dedicated to Shiva.
Constructed primarily by the Rashtrakuta and Yadava dynasties, funded by royals, traders, and the wealthy.
Historically served as temples, pilgrim rest stops, and an important commercial centre.
Currently a major tourist attraction and a protected monument under the Archaeological Survey of India.
timeline: 600–1000 AD: Period when artwork in the caves was created.
1st millennium CE: Deities and mythologies represented in the caves were prevalent.
753-982 AD: Rashtrakuta dynasty period, responsible for part of the Hindu and Buddhist caves.
c. 1187–1317: Yadava dynasty period, responsible for constructing a number of the Jain caves.
important_figures: Royals, traders, and the wealthy of the region (funders)
applications: Religious worship (temples for Hindu, Buddhist, Jain faiths)
Commercial centre (due to location on ancient trade route)
current_status: The Ellora Caves are currently a UNESCO World Heritage Site, a major tourist attraction in the Marathwada region of Maharashtra, and a protected monument under the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), with 34 of its over 100 caves open to the public.
future_prospects: Continued preservation efforts by the Archaeological Survey of India and sustained tourism are expected, ensuring its status as a significant cultural and historical site for future generations.
